text:
You may be able to find a copy of this book “The Show That Never Ends” a block away at Bull Moose.

(There were copies there recently at least.)
author: MEPFuller

text: I also don’t drink champagne out of flutes.
author: MEPFuller

text: White wine glass.
author: MEPFuller

text: That’s an incredible run.
author: MEPFuller

text:
A truth I live by is that, if it’s made of glass, eventually it’ll break.

I used to buy Schott Zwiesel but it hurt too much every time one broke.
author: MEPFuller

text: Mikasa. They’re not exactly fancy, but I do like them.
author: MEPFuller

text: Love the long stem on Iittala. I go back and forth on the bulb shape.
author: MEPFuller

text: I break too many glasses to keep buying Riedel.
author: MEPFuller

text: Mikasa.
author: MEPFuller

text: Finally having the same brand of white wine glasses as my Bordeaux glasses is my drug of choice.
author: MEPFuller

text: Really haven’t been able to stop listening to this playlist about Grenache.
author: MEPFuller

text:
This is a pretty stunning analysis on how much more men are earning on Capitol Hill than women, no matter how you look at the data.

Also, I met the study’s author last night, @CaseyBurgat, and you should definitely follow him.
author: MEPFuller

text: She shouldn’t.
author: MEPFuller

text:

Blaming the media
author: MEPFuller

text: Ignoring his “Twitterhea” actually does normalize it.
author: MEPFuller

text:
What you miss is that hardly any of these bills will become law, and Sinema’s vote will probably never matter on any nominee.

What the President says *does* matter, and allowing politicians to avoid any responsibility to respond to the President is a bad policy.
author: MEPFuller

text: I care a lot less about this individual instance and a lot more about the overall, blanket policy.
author: MEPFuller

text: She can choose to not answer questions, but having a blanket policy where you don’t respond to the President’s tweets is bad.
author: MEPFuller

text:
They’re real divisions. Ignoring them and pretending the President isn’t saying crazy stuff is a dereliction of duty.

It’s actually worse than Paul Ryan saying “I haven’t seen the tweet.”
author: MEPFuller

text: It also lends credence to a terrible policy that Republicans could adopt, which would help Trump and them avoid accountability for his words and their continued support.
author: MEPFuller

text: Really not the issue.
author: MEPFuller

text:
Whether Sinema likes it or not, these are statements from the President, and they’re probably the best insights we have into his administration.

Not answering questions on Trump’s tweet doesn’t serve her constituents or the country better; it helps her avoid political problems.
author: MEPFuller

text: This is a bad policy.
author: MEPFuller

text: Undoubtedly.
author: MEPFuller

text: Can’t unsee it now.
author: MEPFuller

text:
This is like a scene out of Waking Life.

(Is Beto O’Rourke actually just Ethan Hawke without his goatee?)
author: MEPFuller

text: Can anyone in the class who needs a life-saving operation or medication to treat a chronic illness come up with a reason why the free-market might not work in health care?
author: MEPFuller

text: bUt tHeY nEed tHaT m0neY fOr iNnoVatiOn
author: MEPFuller

text:
I’d tell you it amazes me that the best Senate Republicans can muster is vague praise for McCain, rather than firm criticism of the things Trump has said about him recently, but it doesn’t surprise me. At all.

It’s totally consistent.
author: MEPFuller

text: Damn. Omar comin’.
author: MEPFuller

text: He also put the Pentagon Papers into the congressional record, so there’s that.
author: MEPFuller

text:
For the record, I remember Mike Gravel being one of the first presidential candidates to speak at my college in 2007 and I remember thinking then, “Wow, this is definitely not gonna happen.”

That was 12 years ago.
author: MEPFuller

text: We don’t talk about it, but one of the cooler things The Sopranos ever did was refer to $1,000 as “a box of ziti.”
author: MEPFuller

text: “Please contribute to my Kickstarter.”
author: MEPFuller

text: I will be appealing this FOIA response. I hope you understand.
author: MEPFuller

text: Does the $1,600 account for your increase in sandwiches?
author: MEPFuller

text: The very last part of that tweet might have something to do with the penultimate part.
author: MEPFuller

text: What if my faith is believing in a free press?
author: MEPFuller

text: Knowing that Devin Nunes was born in the early 70s, and having seen his yearbook photo before, I have to imagine this one hurts.
author: MEPFuller

text: As an aside, “Devin Nunes’s Mom” would have been a great band name.
author: MEPFuller

text: If one of us has been stealing tweets from the other one, I think I have some receipts in my glovebox or something.
author: MEPFuller

text: “I’m gonna allow it. Overruled.”
author: MEPFuller

text: The thing about Beto O’Rourke standing on counters is that literally Donald Trump is President of the United States.
author: MEPFuller

text: Your Honor, I’d like to submit this article for the record:
author: MEPFuller

text: I, too, am suing for bad tweets.
author: MEPFuller

text: It continues to be awesome that Conor Oberst and Phoebe Bridgers are individually my two favorite artists and they’re playing music together and covering my favorite songs.
author: MEPFuller

text: Yeah but that’s no fun either.
author: MEPFuller

text: I understand women and people of color don’t have it easy on here, but trust me when I tell you I don’t get a pass for being a white male.
author: MEPFuller

text: Meredith, it’s good!
author: MEPFuller

text:
You apparently can’t distinguish between me praising this administration — which I haven’t done many times — and praising Kellyanne Conway for taking a shot at her husband for leaving her with the parenting duties.

You exist as an angry troll, think about that.
author: MEPFuller

text:
You can call things out as bad and not equate them to the holocaust. It doesn’t ever help your argument.

You can also think someone doing bad things occasionally does a good thing, like calling out their spouse for not sharing in parental duties.

Good luck out there.
author: MEPFuller

text: Maybe to someone who flippantly compares things to the holocaust.
author: MEPFuller

text: I actually respect the hell out of Kellyanne Conway taking a backhanded shot at the division of parental duties in an answer about her husband criticizing her boss.
author: MEPFuller

text: C-SPAN really is the best.
author: MEPFuller

text: I’ve never actually noticed this, but staffers flooding out of the House buildings almost exactly at 5 pm is apparently a thing during recess.
author: MEPFuller

text: Fantastic news!
author: MEPFuller

text: Sick reply, bruh.
author: MEPFuller

text:
Be careful making fun of the kid who quit college because the food had sauce on it.

Six months from now, your tweet could be in the first few paragraphs of a viral Buzzfeed piece defending millennials who can’t function in society.

https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/16/style/snowplow-parenting-scandal.html …
author: MEPFuller

text:
Curious to see how this actually plays out in polling, but I’m thinking the GOP attacking a candidate helps that candidate.

Seemed to me like The Online Left’s initial reaction to Beto was cold. Then the GOP classlessly attacked him and, well, I’d just like to see some polling.
author: MEPFuller

text: As they say at Grinnell: Go west, young man.
author: MEPFuller

text: You went to...Calvin College, right??
author: MEPFuller

text: Just look for the kids in BC hats.
author: MEPFuller

text: You never need to ask if someone went to Michigan or Michigan State; they’ll tell you.
author: MEPFuller

text: Hmm yes you’ve really nailed it.
author: MEPFuller

text: This is how the GOP intends to win: Offensive memes.
author: MEPFuller

text: Oh, I get it. Because he’s Irish and Irish people are drunks and DUIs are hilarious and no part of this tweet is gross or offensive.
author: MEPFuller

text: So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.
author: MEPFuller

text: This guy is gonna play.
author: MEPFuller

text:
A Fumé that I have way too often.

The man, the myth:
author: MEPFuller

text: I’ll have you know I’ve never worn plaid *in my life*!
author: MEPFuller

text: I bet that has some fantastic acidity.
author: MEPFuller

text: Folks, it’s Fumé Weather.
author: MEPFuller

text:
What struck me Friday was how much the New Zealand shooter's manifesto sounds like arguments against immigration that I hear in the House, particularly from two Members of Congress.

Judge for yourself:

https://www.huffpost.com/entry/new-zealand-shooter-steve-king-louie-gohmert-rhetoric_n_5c8bf2e4e4b0db7da9f3213c?g7b …
author: MEPFuller

text: And you can read more about this here:
author: MEPFuller

text:
There are so many similarities between how some people talk about immigration and the ideas that influenced this New Zealand shooter. Again, I don't mean to make some gross political point. 

I'm just saying there could be more awareness in how some people talk about immigration.
author: MEPFuller

text: And here's Steve King on defending Western Civilization.
author: MEPFuller

text: Here's the New Zealand shooter on birthrates.
author: MEPFuller

text: And here's Steve King on how, when we import people, we are importing their culture.
author: MEPFuller

text: Here's the shooter on how immigration costs nations their identity.
author: MEPFuller

text: And here's Louioe Gohmert talking about how immigration is an "invasion" at levels unseen since D-Day.
author: MEPFuller

text: Here's the shooter talking about the "invasion" of immigration.
author: MEPFuller

text:
I don't want to turn this horrible shooting into a finger-pointing game, but I was struck by similarities between what the New Zealand shooter wrote and some of the things current Members of Congress say about immigration.

So, a thread:
author: MEPFuller
